Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Solutions for the Global Cooking Problem: Developing Stored Solar Stoves
Award.AbstractNarration:
The World Health Organization asserts around 3 billion people still cook and heat their homes using solid fuels in open fires and leaky stoves. Such cooking and heating produces high levels of indoor air pollution with a range of health-damaging pollutants, including small soot particles that penetrate deep into the lungs. In poorly ventilated dwellings, indoor smoke can be 100 times higher than acceptable levels for small particles. Exposure is particularly high among women and young children, who spend the most time near the domestic hearth. Nearly 2 million people a year die prematurely from illness attributable to indoor air pollution due to solid fuel use. Fuel gathering consumes considerable time for women and children, limiting other productive activities and taking children away from school. In less secure environments, women and children are at risk of injury and violence during fuel gathering. Non-renewable harvesting of biomass contributes to deforestation and thus climate change. Methane and black carbon (sooty particles) emitted by inefficient stove combustion are powerful climate change pollutants. The proposed technology addresses this large market and a corresponding domestic market that seeks green cooking alternatives with a no-fuel and no-flame device that stores energy to cook when the user needs it.

In this proposal, the team proposes a strategy of concurrent (a) research, (b) development, and (c) field testing, with each of the three efforts informing the others. This three-pronged approach uses the lean start-up model which advocates interaction with end users and avoids prolonged R&D around solutions that may not be adopted in the field. The team intends to work with state and national parks to develop prototype grills/stoves for testing, and will also work with local parks, campgrounds, and university/campus facilities to gain input for development of prototypes. Preliminary feedback from park facility managers indicates a very high level of enthusiasm for a green, clean, fuel-free cooking alternative that reduces fire risk, and there are 215,000 state park campsites alone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored solutions for the global cooking problem, that is, the complex reality that 3 billion people cook daily with solid fuels – wood and dung – causing 4 million premature deaths/year, over 20% of climate forcing, widespread deforestation, and the tasking of women and children with arduous and often risky fuel collection.

One outcome of this work was an enhanced understanding of cooking requirements and customs, including the frustrations of many in this market segment with previous attempts by outsiders to impose ill-conceived solar cooking devices. According to our findings, previous solar devices were unacceptable primarily because users wanted high-temperature, portable thermal storage, so that they could cook when and where they like. They want to be able to retain the cooking culture and hearth configuration that they are accustomed to using with fire-based combustion cooking, allowing them, for example, to cook indoors and/or at night using traditional cookware.

Based on this work, we have developed an innovation to collect, store, and cook with solar thermal energy using a portable, low-cost device. It allows users to maintain the familiarity and cultural traditions of their current combustion-based cooking configurations, without fuel, fire, or emissions.

This project allowed us to develop and test prototypes to prove the concept and to test it.  We have cooked a variety of foods from various cultures. We also have used stored thermal energy for food drying, space heating, phone charging and lighting. We continue to develop modifications and refinements based on what we are learning from users.

This project allowed application of user-centered research and design and of lean start-up methodology. We are better able to understand the problem and to create prototypes that help us answer specific questions that inform design decisions. The merit of this approach includes starting with understanding the problem and the users, rather than developing a technology and then seeking an application for it. We are compelled by the problem and persistently learn from users and adapt our approach to develop solutions.

The potential broader impacts of this work are significant. We envision widely distributing stored solar cooking devices among the 3 billion energy impoverished people who cook with solid fuels, thereby reducing household air pollution, global emissions, climate forcing, deforestation, and the risks and lost opportunity costs associated with fuel collection by women and children. We also envision creation of jobs to manufacture the devices and businesses that use the devices to harvest and distribute solar energy. The innovation holds great promise for those among the energy impoverished who cook with solid fuel and for others who are motivated to use renewable solar energy.
